syllabus:
**MA Modern and Contemporary Poetry**

**(ENC)**

Instructor: Dr. Aaron Deveson

Contact time: three hours per week (plus office hours)

**UNIT OUTLINE**

The purpose of the course is to introduce graduate students to some important modern and contemporary poetry in English. The course begins with an introduction to important developments from early in the twentieth century and reaches up to very recent work. In the case of some twentieth-century writers studied on the course, the poetry may be considered “recent” or “contemporary” by dint of the fact that it has only recently been “rediscovered.” Poets from the United States, England, Wales, (Northern) Ireland, Australia, Jamaica, and Saint Lucia, are featured on the course.

Themes include:

*   Developments in idiom and form
*   Traditions and counter-reactions
*   “Mainstream” vs. “innovative” poetries (in this version of the course there will be slightly more emphasis on the former)
*   Cosmopolitanism
*   Cultural authority and post-imperial conditions
*   Satire and political critique
*   New secular myths
*   Ecological poetry and new pastorals
*   The public and private functions of the poet (and what lies in between, including collaboration)
*   Sexualities
*   Poetics and mental health

**TEXTS**

Students will be presented with a dossier of the poems to be discussed in class. Students will generally be required to read around fifteen pages of poetry in preparation for the class each week.

**ASSESSMENT**

Attendance is, as ever, essential for success.

Essay

(3000-3200 words; 70% of total mark)

Students will write an essay on the work of two to three poets studied in the course. Students are encouraged to write about poets who were not read together in the same week of the course. Students may devise their own essay title and are not required to cleave to any particular theoretical or methodological principle in their writing. The completed essay should be emailed to [aaron.c.deveson@gmail.com](mailto:aaron.c.deveson@gmail.com). In the case of late submissions, 5% will be deducted from the raw percentage mark for every day by which the assignment is late.

Oral and visual presentation

(18-20 mins; 30% of total mark)

The presenting student will use but not simply read from Powerpoint slides. The presentation will typically introduce the life and work of a particular writer. It must refer in a general way to at least four poems and provide a detailed analysis of one of those poems. It must contain at least three images.

**SCHEDULE**  

**Weeks 1 and 2**

T.S. Eliot

**Week 3**

Nancy Cunard and Dylan Thomas

**Weeks 4 and 5**

W.H. Auden and Joan Murray

**Weeks 6**

John Berryman and Robert Lowell

**Week 7**

Elizabeth Bishop and John Ashbery

**Week 8**

**HOLIDAY**

**Week 9**

W.D. Snodgrass, Sylvia Plath, Anne Sexton, and Sharon Olds

**Weeks 10 and 11**

Gary Snyder, Robert Bly, James Wright, Galway Kinnell, A.R. Ammons, and W.S. Merwin

**Week 12**

Adrienne Rich and Les Murray

**Week 13**

Frank O’Hara and John Yau

**Week 14**

Ted Hughes and Anne Stevenson

**Week 15**

Seamus Heaney and Eavan Boland (with a nod to W.B. Yeats)

**Week 16**

Derek Walcott and Ishion Hutchinson

**Weeks 17 and 18**

Personal study

(Electronically send copy of essay by deadline)
